title: Taking control of your career | Ethan Evans (Amazon)
key_insights: The Magic Loop: Do your job well, ask how to help, do what's asked, align help with your goals, repeat
Managers help those who help them - building partnerships with leadership is crucial for advancement
When facing failure, own it immediately, communicate proactively with regular updates, and work to fix it fast
Invention can be systematic: spend 2 hours monthly combining existing concepts from your expertise area
Senior managers get stuck because the transition to director requires strategic thinking over tactical execution
In interviews, enthusiasm and showing impact (not just effort) are more important than perfect answers
Career growth requires explicitly stating your goals to your manager - they can't read your mind
Face-to-face conversations can defuse email conflicts and rebuild damaged relationships
topics_discussed: The Magic Loop career advancement framework
Breaking through senior manager career plateau
Systematic invention and patent creation process
Amazon App Store launch failure with Jeff Bezos
Interview best practices and common mistakes
Remote work vs office work debate
Managing up and building manager partnerships
Bias for action vs careful planning balance
memorable_quotes: An owner never says that's not my job
What your manager should do and $4 will get you a cup of coffee at Starbucks. The point of this loop is it's in your control
If I can get away with publicly failing one of the richest and most famous inventors on earth, and then get promoted and finish my career at Amazon very successfully, you can dig out of any hole
frameworks_mentioned: The Magic Loop (5-step career advancement process)
What Got You Here Won't Get You There principles
recommended_for: middle managers transitioning to executive roles
professionals stuck in their current career level
anyone looking to build better relationships with their manager
leaders interested in Amazon's management philosophy
summary: Former Amazon VP Ethan Evans shares his Magic Loop framework for career advancement, tactical advice for recovering from major failures, and insights on systematic invention and leadership development. The episode provides actionable strategies for building manager partnerships and breaking through career plateaus.
